Workday’s AI Lawsuit: When "Too Much Experience" Doesn't Really Pay?
AI in HR: What Could Possibly Go Wrong?
The Bigger Picture: What AI in Hiring Is Really Doing
Who Should Be Paying Attention?
What Can Employers Actually Do?
Some action steps:
Bottom Line
3 min read
Applying for a job in 2025 sometimes feels like yelling into the void. But now we know why: the void may be Workday’s AI, and it might be ghosting you for being

. If you’re over 40, have a solid resume, and still find yourself being passed over for jobs you could do in your sleep—well, you may have just met your match: an algorithm that thinks you peaked in 2002.
Apparently, quite a bit.

A recent federal court decision just greenlit a discrimination lawsuit against Workday, alleging that its AI-powered hiring tools disproportionately reject applicants based on age, race, and disability. The plaintiff, Derek Mobley, says he applied to over 100 jobs using Workday and didn’t get a single interview. He also happens to be Black, over 40, and managing anxiety and depression—three characteristics that, he claims, the AI was all too quick to reject.
Now, it’s one thing to be told you're "overqualified." It's another to be screened out before a human even lays eyes on your resume because a machine decided your birth year made you a risk.
The case,

, is now moving forward as a collective action, potentially opening the door to thousands of other applicants who’ve been filtered out without explanation since 2020. The legal argument? That Workday's algorithm acts as an
of the employers using it—meaning the software vendor can be held directly liable for the alleged bias.
HR professionals once promised AI would reduce bias. What are we possibly getting instead? Bias at scale—just faster and with a nice dashboard.

Workday’s defense is that it just provides the software, and the employers set the rules. But the court didn't buy that pass-the-buck argument. And rightly so—if you're providing the algorithm that does the filtering, you can't exactly claim you're just the pizza delivery guy when it shows up full of anchovies no one asked for.

Here’s the real problem: AI in hiring decisions isn’t just automating resume sorting; it’s potentially codifying the same old biases in a slick, high-tech wrapper. Worse, these systems often lack transparency, so rejected applicants never really know
they were passed over. It’s like being ghosted by someone you've never met.

Government agencies love efficiency and compliance—but if they’re using AI screening tools like Workday’s, they’d better be prepared for some FOIA requests and EEOC complaints. The public sector is held to high standards for equity and transparency, and lawsuits like this one put a bullseye on any HR department relying blindly on automation.

Hospitals are already understaffed, and hiring biases in AI tools could mean missing out on qualified, experienced candidates. The last thing you want is an ER where no one’s over 35 and everyone’s Googling “how to set a broken bone.”
In an industry built on regulation and risk management, biased AI could trigger not just lawsuits, but regulatory investigations. HR tech isn’t exempt from the compliance frameworks banks live under.

Tech companies walk a fine line. They want to push AI innovation but can’t afford to look hypocritical on DEI. Using biased hiring software while championing diversity is like selling umbrellas in a thunderstorm and claiming you just “distribute them.”
Let’s be clear: AI isn’t the enemy. Poorly designed and unaccountable AI is. Employers and vendors alike need to step up.
If the AI’s only consistent pattern is ghosting Black, older, or disabled applicants, it’s not "smart"—it’s a legal liability.
Algorithms are great at sorting data, but humans are still better at judging people. Don't give hiring over to the bots.
If AI is part of your process, disclose it. Let candidates know how it works and what they can do if they believe they were unfairly screened out.
If you're using Workday or any similar tool, push for insight into how their models were built. “Trust us” doesn’t cut it anymore.
This lawsuit against Workday isn’t just a legal test—it’s a cultural reckoning. It forces us to ask whether AI in hiring is helping us find the best people, or just scaling up our worst instincts.
Because if experience, resilience, and a 20-year track record are being used against you by a machine, then the system isn’t just broken—it’s been programmed that way.
And for anyone over 40 wondering why their resume keeps disappearing into the digital ether: it’s not you. It’s the algorithm.
Want help evaluating your own AI and hiring tools for bias and compliance? Let’s talk—before the lawyers do.

Seamless AI Data Integration for Smarter Workforce Management
Current Challenges in Manufacturing Workforce Management
How AI Data Integration Enhances Workforce Management
Real-World Success Stories of AI Integration
Overcoming Barriers to AI Implementation
Future Trends in AI-Driven Workforce Management
2 min read
Explore how AI data integration is revolutionizing workforce management in the manufacturing industry by enhancing efficiency, productivity, and decision-making.

Manufacturing industries face a myriad of workforce management challenges, from fluctuating labor demands to ensuring compliance with labor laws. Traditional methods often rely heavily on manual processes, leading to inefficiencies and potential errors. Scheduling conflicts, overtime costs, and underutilized skills are common issues that can hamper overall productivity.

Moreover, the rapid pace of technological advancements and market demands necessitates a more agile and responsive workforce management system. Companies must adapt to changing production schedules, manage diverse employee skill sets, and maintain high levels of worker engagement and satisfaction. Addressing these challenges requires innovative solutions that can provide real-time insights and predictive capabilities.

AI-driven data integration offers a transformative approach to workforce management. By leveraging advanced algorithms and machine learning, AI can automate and optimize several key processes. Automated scheduling ensures that the right employees are assigned to the right tasks, reducing the likelihood of overstaffing or understaffing.

Predictive labor demand forecasting helps companies anticipate workforce needs based on historical data and market trends. This allows for better planning and resource allocation. Skills matching algorithms can identify the best-fit employees for specific tasks, enhancing productivity and job satisfaction. Real-time analytics provide actionable insights into workforce performance, enabling managers to make data-driven decisions quickly.

The integration of AI into workforce management systems also reduces the administrative burden on HR and operations teams. Manual data entry and time-consuming scheduling tasks are minimized, allowing staff to focus on more strategic activities. Overall, AI data integration leads to improved efficiency, reduced labor costs, and enhanced operational agility.

Several manufacturers have already seen significant improvements by integrating AI into their workforce management systems. For example, a leading automotive parts manufacturer implemented an AI-driven scheduling system that reduced overtime costs by 25% within the first six months. The system's predictive capabilities allowed the company to better align labor supply with production demands, resulting in more efficient use of resources.

Another success story comes from a consumer electronics manufacturer that used AI to enhance skills matching and training programs. By analyzing employee performance data, the company identified skills gaps and provided targeted training to employees. This not only improved productivity but also boosted employee morale and retention rates.
These real-world examples highlight the tangible benefits of AI integration, demonstrating how it can lead to significant cost savings, efficiency gains, and improved employee satisfaction.

Despite the clear benefits, implementing AI-driven workforce management solutions can come with challenges. Change management is a critical component, as employees and managers need to adapt to new ways of working. Effective communication and training are essential to ensure smooth adoption and minimize resistance.

Data integration is another common hurdle. Companies must ensure that their existing systems can seamlessly integrate with new AI technologies. This often requires a thorough analysis of current data infrastructures and the implementation of robust integration frameworks.

Employee adoption is also crucial. Providing adequate training and support can help ease the transition and encourage employees to embrace the new system. Additionally, involving employees in the implementation process can foster a sense of ownership and improve overall acceptance.

Looking ahead, the integration of AI with the Internet of Things (IoT) is expected to further revolutionize workforce management. IoT devices can provide real-time data on equipment performance and worker productivity, enabling more precise and dynamic workforce planning.

Continuous learning systems are another emerging trend. These systems use AI to continuously analyze workforce data and adapt scheduling, training, and performance management strategies in real-time. This allows companies to remain agile and responsive to changing conditions and demands.

Adaptive scheduling, powered by AI, will become more prevalent. These systems can automatically adjust work schedules based on real-time data, ensuring optimal coverage and efficiency. As AI technologies continue to evolve, their integration into workforce management systems will drive further advancements in productivity, efficiency, and employee satisfaction.

Best Practices For Workforce Management Software Implementation
Understanding the Unique Needs of the Hospitality Industry
Ensuring Seamless Integration with Existing Systems
Training Your Team for Maximum Efficiency
Leveraging Data Analytics for Informed Decision Making
Continuous Improvement and Adaptation
1 min read
Implementing workforce management software can revolutionize operations in the hospitality industry, but success hinges on following best practices tailored to this sector.

The hospitality industry is characterized by its dynamic and diverse workforce, which includes full-time, part-time, and seasonal employees. Understanding these unique needs is crucial for implementing an effective workforce management software. Factors such as variable shifts, compliance with labor laws, and the need for real-time scheduling adjustments must be considered.

Tailoring the software to accommodate these specific requirements ensures that the system can handle the complexities of hospitality operations, ultimately leading to improved efficiency and employee satisfaction.

Integrating workforce management software with existing systems such as payroll, HRIS, and ERP is vital for a smooth transition. This integration ensures that data flows seamlessly between systems, reducing the risk of errors and redundancies.

An effective integration strategy includes mapping out all necessary touchpoints, conducting thorough testing, and involving key stakeholders from IT and HR departments. This approach helps to mitigate potential disruptions and ensures that the new software enhances existing processes.

Proper training is essential for maximizing the benefits of workforce management software. A well-structured training program should be tailored to different user groups, including managers, HR personnel, and frontline employees.

Utilizing a 'train the trainer' approach can be highly effective, as it empowers key users to disseminate knowledge throughout the organization. Providing ongoing support and resources, such as user guides and help desks, further ensures that all employees can effectively utilize the new system.

Data analytics is a powerful tool that can provide valuable insights into workforce trends and performance. By leveraging the analytics capabilities of workforce management software, hospitality businesses can make informed decisions that drive operational efficiencies and enhance employee productivity.
Regularly reviewing analytics reports on metrics such as labor cost, overtime, and employee attendance can help identify areas for improvement and enable proactive management of workforce challenges.

The implementation of workforce management software is not a one-time event but an ongoing process. Continuous improvement and adaptation are key to ensuring that the system continues to meet the evolving needs of the hospitality industry.

Regularly soliciting feedback from users, staying updated with software upgrades, and adapting to changes in labor laws and industry standards are essential practices. This commitment to continuous improvement ensures that the software remains a valuable asset for workforce management.

3 min read

At Inovium, we take data security extremely seriously, especially as a GSA contractor trusted with sensitive employee and operational information. The growing trend of cybersecurity incidents within HR and workforce management software underscores the critical importance of vendor selection.
Two cases in recent years highlight the substantial
, and
stemming from cybersecurity failures:

In March 2024, Tyler Technologies, a leading provider of HR and public sector software, suffered a breach exposing personal information including names, Social Security numbers, and driver’s license data.
In December 2021, UKG’s Kronos Private Cloud was hit with a crippling ransomware attack, disrupting critical timekeeping and payroll services for major enterprises and municipalities.
These cases illustrate the core legal vulnerabilities HR software vendors face during a breach:

The breaches at Tyler Technologies and UKG/Kronos resulted in a profound loss of trust among their customers and end users, many of whom depended on these platforms to manage sensitive user data and daily business operations. For Tyler specifically, public sector agencies (traditionally risk-averse and accountability-driven) were forced to reconsider whether Tyler could be trusted with citizen and employee data after the breach exposed Social Security numbers, financial records, and critical infrastructure information. In UKG’s case, the ransomware attack crippled payroll operations across many industries including Public Sector, Manufacturing, and Healthcare for weeks, leaving employees unpaid during the holidays. This failure not only damaged relationships with corporate clients but also created resentment and legal exposure from the employees themselves. Both companies experienced lasting damage to their reputations and client trust, making client retention harder, increasing scrutiny in RFP processes, and significantly raising the cost of acquiring new customers. In industries where confidentiality and reliability are non-negotiable, a single breach often translates to years of reputational recovery, if recovery happens at all.

What is Compensation Planning?

Compensation planning refers to the process of designing and administering a company’s compensation program, which includes determining the salaries, wages, bonuses, benefits, and other forms of rewards that employees receive in exchange for their work.

Compensation planning involves analyzing market data to ensure that a company’s compensation package is competitive and attractive to potential employees, while also aligning with the company’s overall budget and financial goals.
The process also involves developing a compensation philosophy that outlines the company’s approach to pay and rewards, such as whether the company values performance-based pay or tenure-based pay.

Overall, compensation planning is a critical aspect of a company’s overall human resources strategy, as it helps to attract, retain, and motivate employees, while also ensuring that the company’s financial resources are allocated effectively.

pages.title: Workday’s AI Lawsuit: When "Too Much Experience" Doesn't Really Pay?
headlines: Workday’s AI Lawsuit: When "Too Much Experience" Doesn't Really Pay?
AI in HR: What Could Possibly Go Wrong?
The Bigger Picture: What AI in Hiring Is Really Doing
Who Should Be Paying Attention?
What Can Employers Actually Do?
paragraphs: 3 min read
Applying for a job in 2025 sometimes feels like yelling into the void. But now we know why: the void may be Workday’s AI, and it might be ghosting you for being

. If you’re over 40, have a solid resume, and still find yourself being passed over for jobs you could do in your sleep—well, you may have just met your match: an algorithm that thinks you peaked in 2002.
Apparently, quite a bit.

A recent federal court decision just greenlit a discrimination lawsuit against Workday, alleging that its AI-powered hiring tools disproportionately reject applicants based on age, race, and disability. The plaintiff, Derek Mobley, says he applied to over 100 jobs using Workday and didn’t get a single interview. He also happens to be Black, over 40, and managing anxiety and depression—three characteristics that, he claims, the AI was all too quick to reject.
Now, it’s one thing to be told you're "overqualified." It's another to be screened out before a human even lays eyes on your resume because a machine decided your birth year made you a risk.
The case,

, is now moving forward as a collective action, potentially opening the door to thousands of other applicants who’ve been filtered out without explanation since 2020. The legal argument? That Workday's algorithm acts as an
of the employers using it—meaning the software vendor can be held directly liable for the alleged bias.
HR professionals once promised AI would reduce bias. What are we possibly getting instead? Bias at scale—just faster and with a nice dashboard.

Workday’s defense is that it just provides the software, and the employers set the rules. But the court didn't buy that pass-the-buck argument. And rightly so—if you're providing the algorithm that does the filtering, you can't exactly claim you're just the pizza delivery guy when it shows up full of anchovies no one asked for.

Here’s the real problem: AI in hiring decisions isn’t just automating resume sorting; it’s potentially codifying the same old biases in a slick, high-tech wrapper. Worse, these systems often lack transparency, so rejected applicants never really know
they were passed over. It’s like being ghosted by someone you've never met.

Government agencies love efficiency and compliance—but if they’re using AI screening tools like Workday’s, they’d better be prepared for some FOIA requests and EEOC complaints. The public sector is held to high standards for equity and transparency, and lawsuits like this one put a bullseye on any HR department relying blindly on automation.

Hospitals are already understaffed, and hiring biases in AI tools could mean missing out on qualified, experienced candidates. The last thing you want is an ER where no one’s over 35 and everyone’s Googling “how to set a broken bone.”
In an industry built on regulation and risk management, biased AI could trigger not just lawsuits, but regulatory investigations. HR tech isn’t exempt from the compliance frameworks banks live under.

Tech companies walk a fine line. They want to push AI innovation but can’t afford to look hypocritical on DEI. Using biased hiring software while championing diversity is like selling umbrellas in a thunderstorm and claiming you just “distribute them.”
Let’s be clear: AI isn’t the enemy. Poorly designed and unaccountable AI is. Employers and vendors alike need to step up.
If the AI’s only consistent pattern is ghosting Black, older, or disabled applicants, it’s not "smart"—it’s a legal liability.
Algorithms are great at sorting data, but humans are still better at judging people. Don't give hiring over to the bots.
If AI is part of your process, disclose it. Let candidates know how it works and what they can do if they believe they were unfairly screened out.
If you're using Workday or any similar tool, push for insight into how their models were built. “Trust us” doesn’t cut it anymore.
This lawsuit against Workday isn’t just a legal test—it’s a cultural reckoning. It forces us to ask whether AI in hiring is helping us find the best people, or just scaling up our worst instincts.
Because if experience, resilience, and a 20-year track record are being used against you by a machine, then the system isn’t just broken—it’s been programmed that way.
And for anyone over 40 wondering why their resume keeps disappearing into the digital ether: it’s not you. It’s the algorithm.
Want help evaluating your own AI and hiring tools for bias and compliance? Let’s talk—before the lawyers do.

pages.title: Seamless AI Data Integration for Smarter Workforce Management
headlines: Seamless AI Data Integration for Smarter Workforce Management
How AI Data Integration Enhances Workforce Management
paragraphs: 2 min read
Explore how AI data integration is revolutionizing workforce management in the manufacturing industry by enhancing efficiency, productivity, and decision-making.

Manufacturing industries face a myriad of workforce management challenges, from fluctuating labor demands to ensuring compliance with labor laws. Traditional methods often rely heavily on manual processes, leading to inefficiencies and potential errors. Scheduling conflicts, overtime costs, and underutilized skills are common issues that can hamper overall productivity.

Moreover, the rapid pace of technological advancements and market demands necessitates a more agile and responsive workforce management system. Companies must adapt to changing production schedules, manage diverse employee skill sets, and maintain high levels of worker engagement and satisfaction. Addressing these challenges requires innovative solutions that can provide real-time insights and predictive capabilities.

AI-driven data integration offers a transformative approach to workforce management. By leveraging advanced algorithms and machine learning, AI can automate and optimize several key processes. Automated scheduling ensures that the right employees are assigned to the right tasks, reducing the likelihood of overstaffing or understaffing.

Predictive labor demand forecasting helps companies anticipate workforce needs based on historical data and market trends. This allows for better planning and resource allocation. Skills matching algorithms can identify the best-fit employees for specific tasks, enhancing productivity and job satisfaction. Real-time analytics provide actionable insights into workforce performance, enabling managers to make data-driven decisions quickly.

The integration of AI into workforce management systems also reduces the administrative burden on HR and operations teams. Manual data entry and time-consuming scheduling tasks are minimized, allowing staff to focus on more strategic activities. Overall, AI data integration leads to improved efficiency, reduced labor costs, and enhanced operational agility.

Several manufacturers have already seen significant improvements by integrating AI into their workforce management systems. For example, a leading automotive parts manufacturer implemented an AI-driven scheduling system that reduced overtime costs by 25% within the first six months. The system's predictive capabilities allowed the company to better align labor supply with production demands, resulting in more efficient use of resources.

Another success story comes from a consumer electronics manufacturer that used AI to enhance skills matching and training programs. By analyzing employee performance data, the company identified skills gaps and provided targeted training to employees. This not only improved productivity but also boosted employee morale and retention rates.
These real-world examples highlight the tangible benefits of AI integration, demonstrating how it can lead to significant cost savings, efficiency gains, and improved employee satisfaction.

Despite the clear benefits, implementing AI-driven workforce management solutions can come with challenges. Change management is a critical component, as employees and managers need to adapt to new ways of working. Effective communication and training are essential to ensure smooth adoption and minimize resistance.

Data integration is another common hurdle. Companies must ensure that their existing systems can seamlessly integrate with new AI technologies. This often requires a thorough analysis of current data infrastructures and the implementation of robust integration frameworks.

Employee adoption is also crucial. Providing adequate training and support can help ease the transition and encourage employees to embrace the new system. Additionally, involving employees in the implementation process can foster a sense of ownership and improve overall acceptance.

Looking ahead, the integration of AI with the Internet of Things (IoT) is expected to further revolutionize workforce management. IoT devices can provide real-time data on equipment performance and worker productivity, enabling more precise and dynamic workforce planning.

Continuous learning systems are another emerging trend. These systems use AI to continuously analyze workforce data and adapt scheduling, training, and performance management strategies in real-time. This allows companies to remain agile and responsive to changing conditions and demands.

Adaptive scheduling, powered by AI, will become more prevalent. These systems can automatically adjust work schedules based on real-time data, ensuring optimal coverage and efficiency. As AI technologies continue to evolve, their integration into workforce management systems will drive further advancements in productivity, efficiency, and employee satisfaction.

pages.title: Best Practices For Workforce Management Software Implementation
headlines: Best Practices For Workforce Management Software Implementation
Understanding the Unique Needs of the Hospitality Industry
Leveraging Data Analytics for Informed Decision Making
paragraphs: 1 min read
Implementing workforce management software can revolutionize operations in the hospitality industry, but success hinges on following best practices tailored to this sector.

The hospitality industry is characterized by its dynamic and diverse workforce, which includes full-time, part-time, and seasonal employees. Understanding these unique needs is crucial for implementing an effective workforce management software. Factors such as variable shifts, compliance with labor laws, and the need for real-time scheduling adjustments must be considered.

Tailoring the software to accommodate these specific requirements ensures that the system can handle the complexities of hospitality operations, ultimately leading to improved efficiency and employee satisfaction.

Integrating workforce management software with existing systems such as payroll, HRIS, and ERP is vital for a smooth transition. This integration ensures that data flows seamlessly between systems, reducing the risk of errors and redundancies.

An effective integration strategy includes mapping out all necessary touchpoints, conducting thorough testing, and involving key stakeholders from IT and HR departments. This approach helps to mitigate potential disruptions and ensures that the new software enhances existing processes.

Proper training is essential for maximizing the benefits of workforce management software. A well-structured training program should be tailored to different user groups, including managers, HR personnel, and frontline employees.

Utilizing a 'train the trainer' approach can be highly effective, as it empowers key users to disseminate knowledge throughout the organization. Providing ongoing support and resources, such as user guides and help desks, further ensures that all employees can effectively utilize the new system.

Data analytics is a powerful tool that can provide valuable insights into workforce trends and performance. By leveraging the analytics capabilities of workforce management software, hospitality businesses can make informed decisions that drive operational efficiencies and enhance employee productivity.
Regularly reviewing analytics reports on metrics such as labor cost, overtime, and employee attendance can help identify areas for improvement and enable proactive management of workforce challenges.

The implementation of workforce management software is not a one-time event but an ongoing process. Continuous improvement and adaptation are key to ensuring that the system continues to meet the evolving needs of the hospitality industry.

Regularly soliciting feedback from users, staying updated with software upgrades, and adapting to changes in labor laws and industry standards are essential practices. This commitment to continuous improvement ensures that the software remains a valuable asset for workforce management.

pages.title: Data Breaches in HR Software: Heavy Legal and Financial Lessons from Tyler Technologies and UKG (Kronos)
headlines: Data Breaches in HR Software: Heavy Legal and Financial Lessons from Tyler Technologies and UKG (Kronos)
paragraphs: 3 min read

At Inovium, we take data security extremely seriously, especially as a GSA contractor trusted with sensitive employee and operational information. The growing trend of cybersecurity incidents within HR and workforce management software underscores the critical importance of vendor selection.
Two cases in recent years highlight the substantial
, and
stemming from cybersecurity failures:

In March 2024, Tyler Technologies, a leading provider of HR and public sector software, suffered a breach exposing personal information including names, Social Security numbers, and driver’s license data.
In December 2021, UKG’s Kronos Private Cloud was hit with a crippling ransomware attack, disrupting critical timekeeping and payroll services for major enterprises and municipalities.
These cases illustrate the core legal vulnerabilities HR software vendors face during a breach:

The breaches at Tyler Technologies and UKG/Kronos resulted in a profound loss of trust among their customers and end users, many of whom depended on these platforms to manage sensitive user data and daily business operations. For Tyler specifically, public sector agencies (traditionally risk-averse and accountability-driven) were forced to reconsider whether Tyler could be trusted with citizen and employee data after the breach exposed Social Security numbers, financial records, and critical infrastructure information. In UKG’s case, the ransomware attack crippled payroll operations across many industries including Public Sector, Manufacturing, and Healthcare for weeks, leaving employees unpaid during the holidays. This failure not only damaged relationships with corporate clients but also created resentment and legal exposure from the employees themselves. Both companies experienced lasting damage to their reputations and client trust, making client retention harder, increasing scrutiny in RFP processes, and significantly raising the cost of acquiring new customers. In industries where confidentiality and reliability are non-negotiable, a single breach often translates to years of reputational recovery, if recovery happens at all.

. Unlike many vendors, we architect and implement solution with:

pages.title: What is Compensation Planning? - Inovium
headlines: What is Compensation Planning?
paragraphs: Compensation planning refers to the process of designing and administering a company’s compensation program, which includes determining the salaries, wages, bonuses, benefits, and other forms of rewards that employees receive in exchange for their work.

Compensation planning involves analyzing market data to ensure that a company’s compensation package is competitive and attractive to potential employees, while also aligning with the company’s overall budget and financial goals.
The process also involves developing a compensation philosophy that outlines the company’s approach to pay and rewards, such as whether the company values performance-based pay or tenure-based pay.

Overall, compensation planning is a critical aspect of a company’s overall human resources strategy, as it helps to attract, retain, and motivate employees, while also ensuring that the company’s financial resources are allocated effectively.

paragraphs: Traditional consulting firms treat workforce technology like back-office IT. We treat it like a strategic lever. Our consultants understand the operational pressure of plant downtime, labor shortages, compliance demands, and razor-thin margins. That’s why we move fast, build smart, and stay aligned with your shop floor realities.
Whether you’re running a unionized workforce, a 24/7 production schedule, or multiple shifts across distributed sites—we help you gain control over workforce costs, compliance, and performance.

We’ve supported workforce transformations for mid-market manufacturers to global logistics networks. Our clients include discrete, process, and mixed-mode manufacturers with workforce challenges that demand real-time visibility, labor optimization, and compliance confidence.

We implement in under six months using a proven agile approach. Our SCRUM delivery model breaks the project into sprints, ensuring speed, transparency, and continuous value delivery without interrupting your core operations. We deliver quick wins—and lasting results.

We specialize in Infor’s Workforce Management and HCM platforms—leveraging capabilities like automated labor forecasting, dynamic scheduling, geofencing, badge and biometric authentication, and seamless payroll integration. Whether you use Oracle, SAP, or other ERPs, we ensure smooth and scalable integration.

Our implementations result in tangible gains: reduced overtime, improved labor utilization, greater scheduling accuracy, and fewer compliance violations. We build configurable dashboards and analytics that empower plant managers and HR leaders to make informed, real-time decisions.

From union compliance to seasonal ramp-up planning, from fatigue management to multi-site scheduling—we’ve helped manufacturers and distributors across North America solve workforce challenges with agility and precision. Our collaborative style and operational understanding make us a trusted partner across the plant, warehouse, and corporate office.

We don’t upsell software or push a one-size-fits-all template. Our recommendations are based entirely on your workforce goals, production constraints, and growth plans. With Inovium, you're getting objective expertise—not another sales pitch.
We’re not here to sell buzzwords. We’re here to deliver results, fast. If you're tired of bloated firms that overpromise and underdeliver, it’s time to work with a partner that’s built for
reality.

Founded in 2017 by a team of seasoned enterprise software experts, Inovium has grown into a trusted partner for end-to-end enterprise application consulting and implementation services. We combine decades of hands-on experience with forward-thinking agile innovation to help organizations maximize the value of their technology and streamline operations.
Inovium is headquartered in Austin, Texas, with key resources located in California, Florida, Texas, Georgia, and Canada (Toronto).
